## BODY

-   [0452 Dealing with Unhappy Employees](http://www.ieslpod.com/Daily_English/0401_0500/452.html)
- 
**[start of dialogue]**Â   
  
Asa: I donâ€™t know how we got stuck with **reviewing employee complaints**. This has got to be the worst job ever!Â   
  
Samantha: This is important work and somebody has to do it. Come on, letâ€™s get started.Â   
  
Asa: I think itâ€™s **bad for morale** to allow employees to **file complaints**. Weâ€™re all **overworked** and **underpaid**, and most of us are **burned out**.Â   
  
Samantha: How else are **disgruntled employees** going to **voice their grievances**?Â   
  
Asa: Personally, I think itâ€™s stupid for employees to put their complaints on paper. Arenâ€™t they worried about **retaliation from the management**?Â   
  
Samantha: I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s going to happen. The whole point of having this system is to resolve any problems before they **get blown out of proportion**. Itâ€™s to everybodyâ€™s benefit to try to make this work.Â   
  
Asa: On the contrary, I think it makes for a **dysfunctional workplace**: Employees thinking of things to complain about and the management with their **backs up against the wall**. I just donâ€™t get it.Â   
  
Samantha: No, I guess you donâ€™t. If you donâ€™t like how things are done around here, Iâ€™ve got a suggestion for you.Â   
  
Asa: What?Â   
  
Samantha: File a complaint.Â   
  
**[end of dialogue]**

## Details

The title of this episode is â€œDealing with Unhappy Employees.â€ To â€œdeal withâ€ means to take care of a problem, to solve or resolve some sort of problem.Â   
  
Asa says, â€œI donâ€™t know how we got stuck with reviewing employee complaints.â€ To â€œget stuck with (something)â€ is a phrasal verb meaning to be forced to do something that is boring or unpleasant, to have to do something you donâ€™t want to do: â€œI cooked dinner and my wife got stuck with washing the dishes.â€ Asa is saying that he doesnâ€™t know how they got stuck with â€œreviewing,â€ or looking at, employee complaints. A â€œcomplaintâ€ is something negative that is said or written, and usually comes with an explanation about why someone doesnâ€™t like something.Â   
  
Asa says, â€œThis has got to be the worst job ever.â€ Samantha says, â€œThis is important work, and somebody has to do it. Come on, letâ€™s get started,â€ she says. Asa says, â€œI think itâ€™s bad for morale to allow employees to file complaints.â€ â€œMoraleâ€ (morale) is the way that a group of people, especially employees, feel about their jobs (their opinions, what they think about their jobs). Itâ€™s the general feeling that they have. Morale can either be high or low. If you say, â€œMy employees have low morale,â€ you mean theyâ€™re not very interested, theyâ€™re not very happy, theyâ€™re not very excited. The opposite would be high morale.Â   
  
Asa is saying that itâ€™s bad for morale to have the employees â€œfile,â€ or submit (give to the company) their complaints. He says, â€œWeâ€™re all overworked and underpaid, and most of us are burned out.â€ To be â€œoverworkedâ€ means to have too much work and to work too hard, making you tired. We all think that we are overworked, Iâ€™m sure! To be â€œunderpaidâ€ means that you donâ€™t get enough money for the work that you do. Once again, most people think that they are overworked and underpaid. This can cause some people to burn out. To â€œburn outâ€ is a two-word phrasal verb meaning to become tired from having done too much of something for too long. So, if you continue to do the same thing year after year and itâ€™s very difficult, you could eventually burn out; you could get to the point where youâ€™re too tired to want to continue, that youâ€™re no longer effective at what you do.Â   
  
Samantha says, â€œHow else are disgruntled employees going to voice their grievances?â€ â€œDisgruntledâ€ means unhappy, disappointed, perhaps even angry. â€œTo voiceâ€ means to express something in words, to say something. â€œVoice,â€ like â€œburn out,â€ has different meanings in English; take a look at our Learning Guide for some additional explanations of both of those terms. Samantha is saying that she doesnâ€™t know how these upset, angry, disgruntled employees are going to â€œvoice their grievances,â€ are going to tell the company what they donâ€™t like. A â€œgrievanceâ€ is like a complaint that is said or written with an explanation. Often, it is related to people thinking that there is something unfair or that they havenâ€™t been treated right by their company.Â   
  
Asa says, â€œPersonally (in my opinion), I think itâ€™s stupid for employees to put their complaints on paper.â€ â€œOn paperâ€ just means in writing, written down. â€œArenâ€™t they worried about retaliation from the management?â€ â€œRetaliationâ€ means revenge, something that you do to hurt another person who has hurt you. So, if I punch you, you could retaliate and punch me back. Asa is saying that if the employees complain, the company could retaliate against them â€“ could do something negative, something bad to them.Â   
  
Samantha says, â€œI donâ€™t think thatâ€™s going to happen. The whole point (the main reason) of having this system is to resolve any problems before they get blown out of proportion.â€ To â€œresolveâ€ means to solve, to fix or end a problem. So, theyâ€™re trying to fix any problems with the employees before they get blown out of proportion. *To â€œblow (something) out of proportionâ€ means to make it more important or more serious than it really is or than it has to be.* So, youâ€™re trying to stop the problems when theyâ€™re small, before they get too big.Â   
  
Samantha says, â€œItâ€™s to everybodyâ€™s benefit to try to make this work.â€ Asa says, â€œOn the contrary,â€ meaning I think itâ€™s the exact opposite; I disagree with you. He says, â€œOn the contrary, I think it makes for a dysfunctional workplace.â€ Asa is saying that he thinks it â€œmakes for,â€ meaning it causes, a dysfunctional workplace. â€œDysfunctionalâ€ means not functional; not working properly, especially when people have bad relationships with each other. Thereâ€™s a popular expression youâ€™ll read or hear about called â€œthe dysfunctional family.â€ It would be a family that doesnâ€™t communicate very well with each other, doesnâ€™t have good relationships with each other. Asa says, â€œemployees thinking of things to complain about and the management with their backs up against the wall.â€ Asa is saying this is why it causes a dysfunctional workplace, because the employees are thinking of things to complain about and the managers â€“ the management has their backs up against the wall. â€œTo have oneâ€™s back up against the wallâ€ means to be in a position where you donâ€™t have a lot of options or choices, that youâ€™re forced to do something without necessarily having a lot of flexibility.Â   
  
Asa says, â€œI just donâ€™t get itâ€ â€“ I donâ€™t understand. Samantha says, â€œNo, I guess you donâ€™t (meaning no, you donâ€™t understand). If you donâ€™t like how things are done around here, Iâ€™ve got a suggestion for you.â€ Asa says, â€œWhat?â€ Samantha says, â€œFile a complaint.â€ Of course, thatâ€™s what Asa was complaining about: employee complaints.Â   
  
Now letâ€™s listen to the dialogue, this time at a normal speed.

# 01 Getting Up - Jeff's

## GLOSSARY
to get up â€“ to get out of bed; to leave oneâ€™s bedÂ

to wake up â€“ to awaken; to stop sleepingÂ   
* She always leaves her curtains open so that she can wake up with the sunlight.Â

* Are you sure that you can handle taking six classes this semester?Â   
  
covers â€“ the layers of fabric that cover a bed; the cloth material that covers a bed and that keep one warmÂ   
* When my husband sleeps, he always steals the covers and then I get so cold at night!Â   
  
comforter â€“ the top-most, thickest cover for a bed, usually made of feathers or other warm materialÂ   
* In the winter, they sleep under a very thick comforter, but in the summer they donâ€™t use it.Â

* When Marcos saw Maria sleeping on the sofa, he covered her with a light blanket so she wouldnâ€™t be too cold.Â

* Why do people decorate their beds with so many pillows? I only need one to sleep on.Â Â

* They bought new pillowcases to match the color of their bedroom walls.Â

* How often do you change the sheets on your bed?Â

* Do you think that this sweater matches these pants?Â   
  
to go off â€“ to make a loud noise very suddenlyÂ   
* When my alarm went off at 6:00 a.m., I was in the middle of a very good dream.Â   
  
jarring â€“ irritating, unpleasant, or annoying to oneâ€™s earsÂ   
* The children were fighting during the car trip and their arguments became very jarring to their parents.Â   
  
buzzer â€“ an electronic device that makes a long, continuous buzzing sound, similar to that of a flying insect like a flyÂ   
* Many TV game shows use a buzzer when participants answer a question incorrectly.Â   
  
to drive (someone) nuts â€“ to make someone angry, irritated, or crazyÂ   
* Please stop singing that song over and over again. Youâ€™re driving me nuts!Â   
  
wake-up call â€“ a hotel service that calls guests at a time the guest wants to wake them up in the morningÂ   
* He missed his flight because the hotel forgot to give him a wake-up call.Â   
  
early riser â€“ a person who enjoys waking up early in the morningÂ   
* Because Samuel is an early riser, he usually makes breakfast for his wife so that she can sleep a little later.Â   
  
to oversleep â€“ to sleep too late; to sleep past the time that one is supposed toÂ   
* Sasha overslept and missed her biology exam. Do you think her professor will let her take it another day?Â   
  
to sleep in â€“ to sleep later than usualÂ   
* Teenagers love to sleep in on weekends. Sometimes they donâ€™t wake up until noon!

## STORY

The worst part of the day for me is definitely when I have to get up. **Waking up**, that I can handle. But getting up? That, I hate. **The covers** I have on my bedÂ   
are **heavy**, mostly because I have **a comforter as well as a light blanket**. I sleep with two pillows, which for some reason have different color pillowcases. Well, at least the sheets match.Â   
  
I sometimes wake up **before the alarm goes off**. I like to keep the alarm at **a low volume**, with some **classical music**, nothing too jarring. My old **roommate** used to like the **terrible buzzer** that you find on most alarm clocks nowadays, which always used to **drive me nuts**. As I was saying, I sometimes **wake up before the alarm**, usually because of some **noise outside the house**â€”a car **door slamming**, an **alarm going off**, **gunfire**â€”well, okay, not gunfire, but man, is my neighborhood noisy! Of course, when Iâ€™m staying in a hotel, itâ€™s usually easier to just get **a wake up call** from the **hotel** than set the alarm.Â   
  
Iâ€™m not really an e**arly riser**, so I donâ€™t jump out of bed ready to **take on the world**. I get up very **slowly**, usually **one foot on the floor at a time**. Every once in awhile Iâ€™ll oversleep, but not too often. I really love the weekends, when I can **sleep in**.

## STORY

Anyway, I turn on the lights, and try to find the **mouthwash** in the medicine cabinet. I pour a small amount into a cup, **swish it around** for 30 seconds, **gargle**, and **spit**. Not pleasant, but necessary. Then I get out the **floss**. When Iâ€™m done flossing, I pull out the **toothbrush** and the **toothpaste**. I brush and then itâ€™s off to the **shower**.Â Â   
  
I pull the shower **curtain** aside, step into the **tub**, and pull the curtain back. I **turn on** both the hot and the cold water, looking for the **perfect temperature**. I l**ather up with** soap, put some shampoo in my hair, then **rinse and dry off**. Now itâ€™s **shaving** time. I used to own an **electric razor**, but I found it didnâ€™t **shave close enough**. So now Iâ€™m back to the old hand razor. I lather up with shaving cream, and I start to shave. I r**inse the razor** and throw the **disposable blades** in the **trash**. Itâ€™s about 7:00 AM, and Iâ€™m on to **breakfast**.

## GLOSSARY

* The dentist said that I should swish mouthwash around for at least 30 seconds every morning.Â

## GLOSSARY
to get up â€“ to get out of bed; to leave oneâ€™s bedÂ

* I want to make sure we have enough time to get ready in the morning. Should I set the alarm for 6:45 or 7:00?Â   
  
to go off â€“ to make a loud noise very suddenlyÂ   
* Her alarm clock went off very early this morning because she wanted to go running before class.Â

* He is so lazy that sometimes he hits the snooze button seven or eight times before he gets up!Â   
  
to wake up â€“ to awaken; to stop sleepingÂ   
* Please be quiet or youâ€™ll wake up the baby! It took two hours to get him to sleep.Â Â

* Last night, Beth didnâ€™t come home until 4:30 a.m. Sheâ€™s such a night owl!Â

* Roberto is an early bird. By 7:00 a.m. he has already taken a shower, made breakfast, cleaned the house, and read the newspaper.Â

* Ice cream is my favorite food and I often splurge by buying the most expensive kind at the store.Â

* She said that she couldnâ€™t sleep very well last night because the mattress was too hard.Â

* When I was in my bedroom, I thought that these socks matched, but when I went outside into the sunlight, I saw that they were different colors.Â

* She keeps her robe hanging on the back of the bathroom door.Â

## STORY

On a weekday, I usually **get up** around 6:30 a.m., but I **set my alarm** to **go off** at 6:20 so that I can hit the **snooze button** to sleep another 10 minutes. My roommate thinks Iâ€™m crazy, but doing this in the mornings actually helps me wake up. Iâ€™m **a night owl**, not **an early bird** like she is, so I need an extra few minutes to **get going** in the morning. 

One reason itâ€™s so hard to get up is because my bedroom and my bed are so comfortable. I **splurged** and bought a bed with a very soft, **thick mattress**. I also have matching **sheets** and **pillowcases**, and a **comforter** that is made of **goose down**. Even my nightstand matches my sheets and the rest of my bedroom. I decorated it so that it would be restful after a busy day at work. 

When I get up, **the first thing I do** is put on my **robe**. Itâ€™s always **so cold** in the apartment in the mornings, no matter what time of year it is. Then, I usually **make my bed**. I hated making my bed when I was little, but now itâ€™s become a **routine**. Sometimes, though, Iâ€™m so tired that I **sleep in** for just a little too long and then, the bed definitely doesnâ€™t get made. On those days, I wish I could sleep in all day!

2. When the alarm goes off, what will I usually do, so that I could sleep longer?
3. Why I always wear a robe in the morning all year around?

/notes/ieslpod/A-Day-in-the-Life-of-Lucy.title: 05 Taking Public Transportation to Work - Lucy's Day
/notes/ieslpod/A-Day-in-the-Life-of-Lucy.content:
Story
	I like my job but it **takes over an hour** to get there from my part of town. First, I walk three blocks to the **subway station** and swipe my **monthly pass** to get through the turnstile. I wait on the platform for the first express train. I get on and since itâ€™s so crowded during the morning hours, there **arenâ€™t any seats** and I stand, holding onto a handrail. At my stop, I get off and **transfer to a second train** that will get me to Union Station. This one isnâ€™t as crowded and I **manage to find a seat**.Â Â  
	When the train gets to Union Station, I get off the train, go up the stairs, and go out of the front exit **to the bus stop**. I get on the B bus to downtown and **show my bus pass** to the bus driver. I sit down near the front of the bus and when three more people get on board, the driver starts on the route. When we get **close to my stop**, I **press the button** to signal to the driver that I need to get off and the bus **pulls up to the next stop**. I get off and **walk half a block** to the **building where I work**. Itâ€™s a long commute, but I look around every morning and I see that Iâ€™m not the only one who has to do it.

/notes/ieslpod/A-Day-in-the-Life-of-Lucy.title: 06 Note Jun 27, 2022 - 06 At My Desk and at Lunch - Lucyâ€™s
/notes/ieslpod/A-Day-in-the-Life-of-Lucy.content:
I get to the office and **sit down at my desk**. I share a **cubicle** with another employee, Jim, but he only works in the afternoons so we donâ€™t usually get in each otherâ€™s way too much. I boot up my computer and look at my **agenda for today**. I had about 30 new emails in my inbox but I decide not to read them right away. There were some **new inter-office paperwork** in my inbox too, but I decide to look at them a little later. First, I wanted to start in **on a report** that I had to finish today. I had a conference call at the end of the day with the head office, but I had most of the day to get it done.  ^73f304

Before long, it was the lunch hour. I **didnâ€™t pack a lunch** so I ask my supervisor if she wanted to have lunch together. We head down the street to **a sit-down restaurant**. The **hostess** shows us to a **table** in the back of the restaurant. The waiter arrives a few minutes later and we **order entrees**, no appetizers, since we need to get back by 1:00. The waiter was very busy so I had to wave him down to **get the check**. He brought the bill, and my supervisor and I **split the check**. We walk back to the office and I get back to work. Just four more hours until quitting time! 

"entree," is the main part of your meal, what we would call the main course.

[Memo](notes/ieslpod/A%20Day%20in%20the%20Life%20of%20Jeff/06%20At%20My%20Desk,%20on%20Break,%20and%20at%20Lunch%20-%20Jeff's%20Day.md#^73a795) is very common for office today

/notes/technic/how-to-set-up-your-first-.title: how to set up your first R2S equipment
/notes/technic/how-to-set-up-your-first-.content:
# How to set up your first R2S system

## Plug in the power cable let it play

When you open your package, you will see an R2S mini machine and a set of power cables with the charger. Remember that **the charger must be the 5V2A~3A if you buy it yourself.**

Then you could plug the SD card into your R2S machine, connect the power cable, and you will **see the `sys light` begins to flash. That means the R2S machine is working now.**

![sys light begins to flash](notes/images/Pasted%20image%2020220416132530.png)

##  Let your computer connect to your R2S

Use an internet data cable to connect your laptop with your R2S, and check if your computer had received the IP address.

![connect your R2S with your laptop](notes/images/Pasted%20image%2020220416132606.png)



If everything goes well, you can type the IP gate address in your internet broswer(e.g. Chrome or IE Explorer) then it will open a website for you, like this.

![the webpage of R2S website](notes/images/Pasted%20image%2020220416132331.png)

### The default user name & password

- The Default IP address: `192.168.2.1`
- The Default User Name: `root`
- The Default Password: `password`

## How to set up your OpenWrt system

### Set up the internet interface

Open `Network` -- `Interface` **then you must decide your home's network is dialing by your router or by your R2S**.


### Dialing by your original router.

If your home's internet is dailed by your original router, you should press the `WAN`--`Revise` button.

![revising your WAN interface ](notes/images/Pasted%20image%2020220416133310.png)
